content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Locate a Coursera Guided project related to 'Astrophysics' suitable for advanced learners. Mention the course duration, the institution offering it, and the main subjects covered in the course.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find a Coursera Guided project related to 'Astrophysics', I need to use the search function. The search button is labeled [2]. Clicking this will likely open a textbox where I can enter the keyword "Astrophysics".
Action: Click [2]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search textbox is now visible at [1] and ready for input. I need to type "Astrophysics" into this textbox to search for relevant guided projects.
Action: Type [1]; Astrophysics
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The results showing currently are not specific to 'Astrophysics' or Guided Projects; they seem to be general courses or professional certificates related to AI and cloud technologies. To refine the search, I need to look for filter options or scroll to see if any astrophysics-related guided projects are present.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The courses visible in this screenshot are still unrelated to 'Astrophysics' and are mostly about cloud, data science, and AI topics. None of these are guided projects or related to astrophysics. To continue the search, scrolling further down may reveal more relevant courses.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: One of the visible courses is "Astronomy: Exploring Time and Space" offered by the University of Arizona, which is somewhat related to astrophysics, but it is listed as a "COURSE" and not explicitly as a "Guided Project." I still do not see a guided project directly related to astrophysics and suitable for advanced learners. Additional scrolling or filter searching might be needed, but for now, I should check for more options further down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible courses are related to quantum computing, optics, and astrobiology, but none are labeled as "Guided Project," which is important for the task. The left panel has filters, but none for Guided Projects are visible. I need to scroll further or look for additional filter options that could narrow the results to "Guided Projects."
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There is a physics course "Understanding Modern Physics I: Relativity and Cosmology" by The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, which is advanced and closely related to astrophysics, but it is labeled as a COURSE, not a Guided Project. Still, no Guided Project is shown. The page continues to show courses and not Guided Projects, indicating a need to filter by project type, which may require checking filter expansion options.
Action: Click [10]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Expanding the subject options did not reveal a filter for course type (e.g., Guided Project). What’s needed is a filter on the page to toggle the type of learning experience to "Guided Project." This is not shown now; therefore, I should scroll down the left filters or the window to find such filtering options.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible courses "From the Big Bang to Dark Energy" and "The Evolving Universe" are both astrophysics/physics-related but are classified as "COURSE," not "Guided Project." There is still no specific filter or label for guided projects in astrophysics. Further search/filtering options may be available further down or in another filter category.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: "AstroTech: The Science and Technology behind Astronomical Discovery" by The University of Edinburgh is a course closely related to astrophysics, suitable for advanced learners. However, it is labeled as a "COURSE," not a "Guided Project." There are still no visible guided projects related to astrophysics. More scrolling may be required, or filtering for project type if available.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible results still do not include any "Guided Project" related to astrophysics, only standard courses. No filter option for project type is visible in the screenshot. More scrolling may be needed, or searching specifically for "Guided Project" rather than "Astrophysics" might help.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.62
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current visible options include "Astro 101: Black Holes" by the University of Alberta (course) and "Big History - From the Big Bang until Today" by University of Amsterdam; both are labeled as "COURSE," not "Guided Project." Still, there are no guided projects in astrophysics, and scrolling is yielding only more courses, not projects.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.65

I should investigate the "Coursera Project Network" option (at [32]) as it most likely corresponds to a guided project.
Action: Click [32]
Confidence: 0.95
